Captain CRAIG asked the Chief Secretary whether his attention had been called to the last report of the resident medical superintendent of Waterford District Lunatic Asylum, dated 13th June, in which he referred to the unusual number of 1091 assistants who had been confined to bed with various ailments; whether he was aware that one of the attendants had stated that, although the hours of duty performed by the attendants were far in excess of other workers, everything pointed to an increase in that direction owing to the number of attendants on the sick list, and to such an extent were the staff overworked that they were deprived of every third Sunday off, which ran their rest up to the sixth Sunday; and whether, in view of the number of cases which had been brought to light of overworking attendants in asylums in Ireland, he would take steps to ensure that their hours were shortened to something approximating the ordinary working day?

comment._content:
From the Freeman's Journal, Monday, 21 March 1881 (the very earliest this photo could have been taken is 1884):
The annual report of Dr. Ringrose Atkins, M.D., of the Waterford District Lunatic Asylum, is a prompt, business-like, and detailed account of that institution. 1880 seems to have been a heavy year in the Asylum. There were 31 men and 43 women admitted during that period. The increase in the number under treatment involved an increase of nearly £600 in the expenses. The Doctor has to congratulate himself, however, on the Asylum's entire immunity from cases of suicide, serious accident, or epidemic. The mortality was much less than that of 1879. Games, plays, sea-side trips, and a library are the greatest aids to medical science in the treatment of the unfortunate insane; and those are used to the fullest measure and with the utmost liberality, under the kindly regime of Dr. Atkins and the Board of Governors, who have expressed their confidence in his conduct of the institution. The reports of Drs. Nugent and Hatchell are also favourable, and altogether we have never read a cheerier account of one of those places which, within the memory of the young amongst us, were looked upon as the joyless, hopeless prisons of a tortured chain-gang of lunatics, leading a life worse than the most painful death.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 67734109@N00
comment._content: I have a number of questions for the knowledgeable out there. Are the wall paintings from scripture? (Near picture, horse and rider or camel and rider?) Why do all but one of the framed portraits seem to be of children? Is the remaining picture a battle scene? What would the base wall color have been? How many and what colors have been in the stenciling above the wainscoting? (I seem to see three from tonal qualities alone) Why are the tables split? I will venture that they are institutional tables from the start as there are no sharp edges (save for where they split) on any edge or corner on both wood and metalwork. Was the large skylight common in this period? I noted one in the McNeill's Saloon photo as well.
